channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Azerbaijan Jails Reporter Who Angered Top Officials
item.description: The arrest of a journalist who has reported on the business dealings of the president’s family was a further indication of Azerbaijan’s deteriorating relations with the West.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: Couple Tried in Qatar Feared Further Delays After Acquittal
item.description: Matthew and Grace Huang of Los Angeles faced a two-year legal struggle after the death of their adopted daughter.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Senate Panel Faces New Obstacle to Release of Torture Report
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry warned Senator Dianne Feinstein that the release of the long-delayed review could ignite unrest in the Middle East and endanger hostages.
item.dc:creator: By MARK MAZZETTI and CARL HULSE

item.title: Signs That Attackers Came From Within Mitigate Alarm in Chechnya
item.description: Local militants have claimed responsibility for an attack that killed 14 police officers and at least one civilian, easing concerns that the Islamic State had been involved.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: People gathered on Friday at the scene of the previous day’s attack. Early indications pointed to a local radical group, not fighters linked to the Islamic State.

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Syria: Militants Say They Killed a Lebanese Soldier
item.description: A Syrian extremist group linked with Al Qaeda said on Friday that it had killed a Lebanese soldier.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Italy: Mayor May Have to Hang Up His Bike
item.description: The mayor of Rome is considering whether to stop using his bicycle to get around the city after local gangsters were heard in intercepted phone conversations saying that he needed to be driven from office or possibly even eliminated.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Mexico: Police Chief Says He Is Stepping Down
item.description: Under fire over accusations of police brutality, Mexico City’s police chief, Jesús Rodríguez Almeida, resigned on Friday.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: World Briefing: Pakistan: Children May Have Been Infected with H.I.V.
item.description: The Health Ministry said on Friday that it was investigating a report that 10 children had been infected with H.I.V. after receiving blood transfusions.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Sunnis Fear Permanent Displacement From Iraqi Town
item.description: Jurf al-Sakhar was recaptured from the Islamic State, but now Shiite-dominated forces say Sunnis cannot return to their homes for at least eight months.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: Iraqi soldiers in Jurf al-Sakhar, Iraq, in August as they moved against Islamic State fighters. The Shiite-dominated security forces were aided by militias.

item.title: British Court Rules in Favor of Electronic Surveillance
item.description: The decision comes after a global outcry against programs like Prism, which have given spy agencies almost unfettered access to Internet communications.
item.dc:creator: By MARK SCOTT

item.title: News Analysis: British Noses, Firmly in the Air
item.description: What snobs really think about the little gits and plebs.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Britain Puts 2 in Prison After Return From Syria
item.description: The case has provoked a debate over how to handle returning jihadists without discouraging their families from cooperating with the authorities.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE and MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Lens Blog: African Diasporas, Playing With the Past
item.description: A Senegalese has recreated portraits made centuries ago of Africans who lived in Europe and were commemorated in now-forgotten Western art.
item.category: The Image of the Black in Western Art
item.dc:creator: By JEAN-PHILIPPE DEDIEU
item.media:description: Olaudah Equiano (1745–97), known in his lifetime as Gustavus Vassa, was a prominent African in London, a freed slave who supported the British movement to end the slave trade. Original engraving by an unknown artist.

item.title: Twin Bombings Hit a Cafe in Somalia
item.description: The explosions, one by a suicide bomber and the other a car bomb, occurred by a restaurant in Baidoa, south of Mogadishu, that is popular journalists and government officials.
item.dc:creator: By MOHAMMED IBRAHIM

item.title: World Briefing: Germany’s Left Party Takes Its First Governor’s Seat
item.description: Bodo Ramelow of the Left Party, which is made up of ex-Communists and former Social Democrats, was installed as governor of the state of Thuringia in the east.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: British Judge Lifts Restriction on Sending Books to Prisoners
item.description: A policy had prohibited inmates from receiving books unless they had earned the right through good behavior to buy them through the Prison Service.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: China Arrests Ex-Chief of Domestic Security in Graft Case
item.description: The former head of the domestic security apparatus is the first member of the Politburo Standing Committee, retired or active, to face a criminal corruption inquiry.
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Zhou Yongkang before relinquishing power in 2012. He is accused of bribetaking, leaking secrets and helping his allies enrich themselves at state expense.

item.title: France to Pay Holocaust Survivors Over Deportations
item.description: Under a deal negotiated with the United States, France is expected to pay $60 million to survivors for using its national railway for deportations during World War II.
item.category: SNCF (Societe Nationale des Chemins de fer Francais)
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Pakistani Children Infected With H.I.V. From Transfusions, Report Says
item.description: The 10 children were receiving regular transfusions to treat a blood disease called thalassemia.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD
item.media:description: A mother sat alongside her son, a thalassemia patient, as he received blood at a treatment center in Peshawar on Thursday. Pakistani health officials are investigating a report that 10 children were infected with H.I.V. by blood transfusions.

item.title: Greek Statue Travels Again, but Not to Greece
item.description: The British Museum plunged itself into a geopolitical tempest with the loan of one of the famous Elgin marbles of Greece to the Hermitage.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Children could only read about the statue of Ilissos on Friday at its temporarily empty spot in the British Museum in London.
